[Outro]

This outro contains three distinct sections: The gospel section, the coda, and the piano outro.

Gospel section
This first section uses the concept of repeating a melodic phrase with the always-thickening arrangement. First, we have the main tune for the bass voices (Brian May, Freddie Mercury). Then we add octave harmonies and also drums with slow gradual crescendo throughout the section. Then the fifth and thirds enter with soprano octaves (Roger Taylor, John Deacon) added. Then, the soprano thirds come in with different punctuation, also handclaps and bass fade in. Then finally, the phrase extends with an oscillating last syllable and the extra high note on  “…love”. The next phrase is a variant of the opening phrase of the song (or vice versa), with Freddie’s voice soloed. The last syllable is an 11-note pentatonic melisma. When then hear the coda.

Coda
The coda sings the same eight-measure phrase seven times with Mercury singing along with semi-improvised vocals. The chord progression is mainly the same, only the harmonic rhythm is faster for the last two chords. The vocal harmony is tightly arranged.

Piano Outro
The short outro is an extension of the ending phrase of the coda. It starts with a slow down, then Freddie plays on the piano some trills and ad-lib figures. The song closes with a staccato chord on the tonic.
[Intro]

The song starts with an almost acapella intro with soft piano backing that has five phrases of irregular length. All multitracked by the band (Freddie Mercury, Brian May, Roger Taylor, John Deacon), both the first and last phrase have merely one syllable each. A variant of this section will be shown up toward the end of the gospel section, which is also a variant of the end chorus. The second part of the intro is played on the piano with the drums and bass entering on the upbeat. While the piano line instantly establishes the ¾ meter, we have a chain of disorienting hemiolas. We then break into the first verse.
They say I got a lot of water in my brain

Hydroencephalus, better known as “water on the brain,” is a condition in which fluid builds up in the cranium. Symptoms can include memory loss or poor temper control. In this line, Mercury is stating that people have been telling him something’s wrong with him in his desperate search for love, as the line before this makes clear— “They say I’m goin' crazy!”

Can anybody find me
 Somebody to love?

Throughout this song, the refrain “Can anybody find me somebody to love?” is used with a dual meaning. The obvious meaning is that he’s asking anybody in the world to find him a person he can love. The second meaning is a result of his insecurity at failing to find love. He’s wondering if there’s anybody in the world that would find him deserving of their love.
Also worth mentioning that this line has bisexual context, since it relates perfectly with the hardships on finding love with homophobia around.

I’m okay, I’m alright (He’s alright, he’s alright)
 I ain’t gonna face no defeat (Yeah, yeah)

An entire turnaround from the slightly defeatist attitude that Freddie embodies earlier in the song. He’s determined to find somebody he can bond with. No longer is he whining in the mud. This is Freddie at his best: a determined man with his mind set on a single goal. That goal is love.

Additionally, although unrelated to the actual lyrics, there is a point in the song (2:50 to be precise) where there’s a high sound, often mistaken for Brian May’s guitar. In actual fact, this is drummer Roger Taylor’s amazing falsetto in action.

Got no feel, I got no rhythm
 I just keep losin’ my beat (You just keep losing and losing)

He feels really awkward when he talks to other people. He lacks the warmth and charm that other guys might have, and feels that is why he is so unsuccessful in finding someone to love.



He wishes it were easier for him, but can’t find any method to help his results.

He’s used to hearing the word “no” – there are no wins for him, just losses. Perhaps Mercury’s also lost a bit of himself along the way – the phrase “losing [their] beat” often refers to when someone gets lost with their identity.

(He works hard) everyday (Everyday)
 I try and I try and I try
 But everybody wants to put me down

He wants to find love with somebody, but no one will give him a chance. No matter how much he alters himself so that he can be what people want, he’s never the first choice.

He feels that he is unlovable and always screws things up for himself, and the depression that stems from his need for a significant other is dragging him down.

Ooh, each morning I get up I die a little
 Can barely stand on my feet
Freddie Mercury’s Depression and loneliness take their toll. It affects his everyday life, even waking up feels like a chore without someone there.

I just gotta get out of this prison cell
 (One day) Someday I’m gonna be free, Lord
This line could be related to sexual orientation. He’s living in a homophobic society that forces him to be someone he’s not, and he wishes to be free of that prison cell someday.

(Take a look at yourself in the mirror and cry)
 Take a look in the mirror and cry
 Lord, what you’re doin’ to me (Yeah, yeah)
 I have spent all my years in believin’ you
 But I just can’t get no relief, Lord

Mercury was religious; he was a faithful practitioner of Zoroastrianism. Zoroastrianism is deeply rooted in the power of a supreme god, and Freddie is frustrated that the God he worships will not grant him a lover.

Zoroastrianists believe that doing good deeds is the only way to keep chaos at bay. Mercury proclaims that he’s always been faithful towards his God but still hasn’t been rewarded with love.
